issues.title: Missing Food Service Director Qualifications Requirements
issues.description: While BP 3551 states that food service directors must possess qualifications required by 7 CFR 210.30 and CDE standards, neither the policy nor regulation specifies what these qualifications are or how compliance will be ensured. Federal regulations require specific educational, training, and experience requirements for food service directors.

legal_citations.text: Each school food authority shall employ a food service director who meets minimum qualifications established by the State agency. At a minimum, the food service director shall have education, training, or experience in food service management and business management.

issues.required_language: The food service director shall possess at minimum: (1) A bachelor's degree, or (2) An associate's degree or equivalent coursework, plus school food service experience, or (3) A high school diploma or equivalent, plus school food service experience, plus additional training as specified by the California Department of Education. The food service director must also complete annual continuing education/training hours as required by state and federal regulations.

issues.title: Missing Professional Standards Training Requirements
issues.description: While BP 3551 mentions annual training by CDE, neither document specifies the detailed professional standards training requirements mandated by federal law for food service personnel, including specific hour requirements and training topics.

legal_citations.text: Not later than July 1, 1999, the Secretary shall establish professional standards for school food service personnel... Such standards shall include minimum training, education, and certification requirements for food service directors and managers.

issues.required_language: Food service directors must complete a minimum of 12 hours of annual continuing education/training. Food service managers must complete a minimum of 10 hours of annual continuing education/training. Training must cover food safety, nutrition, and program administration topics as specified by USDA and CDE requirements.

issues.title: Missing Wellness Policy Integration Requirements
issues.description: Neither the policy nor regulation addresses the requirement to ensure food service operations align with the district's wellness policy, particularly regarding competitive food standards and nutrition education integration.

legal_citations.text: Each local educational agency participating in a program authorized by this Act or the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 shall establish a local school wellness policy... The local wellness policy shall include... guidelines for reimbursable school meals that are not less restrictive than regulations and guidance issued by the Secretary.

issues.required_language: Food service operations shall comply with and support the district's wellness policy, including nutrition standards for all foods and beverages sold or served on campus during the school day. The Superintendent or designee shall ensure coordination between food service operations and wellness policy implementation.

issues.title: Missing Specific Civil Rights Compliance Language
issues.description: While the documents address non-discrimination in meal service, they lack specific language regarding civil rights compliance and complaint procedures required for federally funded nutrition programs.

legal_citations.text: School food authorities shall comply with the nondiscrimination requirements... and shall provide assurance that no child will be discriminated against because of race, color, national origin, sex, age, or disability.

issues.required_language: The district shall comply with all applicable civil rights laws and regulations in the operation of child nutrition programs. The district shall provide information on how to file a civil rights complaint and shall post required civil rights statements in accordance with USDA requirements.
